content.name: p
children: You typically obtain a Git repository in one of two ways:

children.name: li
children: You can take a local directory that is currently not under version control, and turn it into a Git repository, or

children.name: li
children: You can

children.name: em
children: clone
an existing Git repository from elsewhere.

content.name: p
children: In either case, you end up with a Git repository on your local machine, ready for work.

content.name: h2
children: Initializing a Repository in an Existing Directory

content.name: p
children: If you have a project directory that is currently not under version control and you want to start controlling it with Git, you first need to go to that project's directory.
If you've never done this, it looks a little different depending on which system you're running:

content.name: p
children: for Linux:

content.name: Fence
children: $ cd /home/user/my_project

content.name: p
children: and type:

content.name: Fence
children: $ git init

content.name: p
children: This creates a new subdirectory named

children.name: code
children: .git
that contains all of your necessary repository files -- a Git repository skeleton.
At this point, nothing in your project is tracked yet.
See <<ch10-git-internals#ch10-git-internals>> for more information about exactly what files are contained in the

children.name: code
children: .git
directory you just created.

content.name: p
children: If you want to start version-controlling existing files (as opposed to an empty directory), you should probably begin tracking those files and do an initial commit.
You can accomplish that with a few

children.name: code
children: git add
commands that specify the files you want to track, followed by a

children.name: code
children: git commit

content.name: Fence
children:
$ git add *.c
$ git add LICENSE
$ git commit -m 'Initial project version'

content.name: p
children: We'll go over what these commands do in just a minute.
At this point, you have a Git repository with tracked files and an initial commit.

content.name: h2
children: Cloning an Existing Repository

content.name: p
children: If you want to get a copy of an existing Git repository -- for example, a project you'd like to contribute to -- the command you need is

children.name: code
children: git clone
If you're familiar with other VCSs such as Subversion, you'll notice that the command is "clone" and not "checkout".
This is an important distinction -- instead of getting just a working copy, Git receives a full copy of nearly all data that the server has.
Every version of every file for the history of the project is pulled down by default when you run

children.name: code
children: git clone

In fact, if your server disk gets corrupted, you can often use nearly any of the clones on any client to set the server back to the state it was in when it was cloned (you may lose some server-side hooks and such, but all the versioned data would be there -- see <<ch04-git-on-the-server#_getting_git_on_a_server>> for more details).

content.name: p
children: You clone a repository with

children.name: code
children: git clone <url>
For example, if you want to clone the Git linkable library called

children.name: code
children: libgit2
, you can do so like this:

content.name: Fence
children: $ git clone https://github.com/libgit2/libgit2

content.name: p
children: That creates a directory named

children.name: code
children: libgit2
, initializes a

children.name: code
children: .git
directory inside it, pulls down all the data for that repository, and checks out a working copy of the latest version.
If you go into the new

children.name: code
children: libgit2
directory that was just created, you'll see the project files in there, ready to be worked on or used.

content.name: p
children: If you want to clone the repository into a directory named something other than

children.name: code
children: libgit2
, you can specify the new directory name as an additional argument:

content.name: Fence
children: $ git clone https://github.com/libgit2/libgit2 mylibgit

content.name: p
children: That command does the same thing as the previous one, but the target directory is called

children.name: code
children: mylibgit

content.name: p
children: Git has a number of different transfer protocols you can use.
The previous example uses the

children.name: code
children: https://
protocol, but you may also see

children.name: code
children: git://
or

children.name: code
children: user@server:path/to/repo.git
, which uses the SSH transfer protocol.
<<ch04-git-on-the-server#_getting_git_on_a_server>> will introduce all of the available options the server can set up to access your Git repository and the pros and cons of each.

frontmatter.description: How to configure and initialize a git repository.
